metadata.title: tSNE Degrades to PCA. At large Perplexity | by Nikolay Oskolkov | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: This is the sixteenth article from the column Mathematical Statistics and Machine Learning for Life Sciences where I try to explain some mysterious analytical techniques used in Bioinformatics and…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Mathematical Statistics and Machine Learning for Life Sciences

all_paragraphs: This is the sixteenth article from the column Mathematical Statistics and Machine Learning for Life Sciences where I try to explain some mysterious analytical techniques used in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology in a simple way. In my previous post, tSNE vs. UMAP: Global Structure, I touched the limit of large perplexity as a potential way for tSNE to preserve more of a global data structure that becomes important when attempting to use tSNE beyond visualization for addressing hierarchical relations between clusters of data points (clustering). Here I will describe in more details some pitfalls that arise when using tSNE with a large perplexity, such as a transformation of the non-linear tSNE into a linear PCA dimension reduction.

As the sizes of data sets grow, e.g. in the scRNAseq field it is almost a routine to work with hundreds of thousands or even millions of cells, using tSNE with large perplexities beyond recommended (between 5 and 50) on the large data sets becomes more and more common for robust discovery of data structure. Indeed, using default perplexity on a large data set may not be informative as it often leads to less distinct clusters of data points as it was shown in several publications, for example in this great post, see also a good discussion here.
Even for a well-behaved MNIST benchmark data set, the difference between small and large perplexity is obvious: larger perplexity leads to more distinct clusters in the tSNE dimension reduction plot.

This becomes increasingly more and more important as the size of a data set grows. The second reason why you might want to increase perplexity values using tSNE on large data sets is the long-standing hypothesis (see for example here and here) that tSNE may preserve more of a global data structure at large perplexity, comparable in this way with UMAP. To demonstrate this let us simulate 3 Gaussian blobs (1000 points each) of 2D data points: two blobs close to each other and far away from the third one.
Now we will try to reconstruct the original data running tSNE with different perplexity values: 10, 30, 100 and 1000.

Here we can make two important observations. First, at low perplexity values 10 and even 30, the data structure is not obvious. Indeed, if I did not color the points it would be even hard to guess how many blobs we see in the tSNE plots for perplexity 10 and 30 as the data points seem to form somewhat dumbbell clusters. Therefore, in order to resolve all three clusters we needed to increase the perplexity value up to 100. Second, note that at perplexity equal to 10, 30 and 100 the three clusters seem to be equidistant, although we know that two of them should be located together and separated from the third one. Correct relative positions of the clusters (global data structure), were only achieved when we increased the perplexity up to 1000, i.e. far beyond recommended values between 5 and 50. Hence, the large perplexity limit becomes crucial for biological interpretation of closeness of cell populations from a tSNE plot on scRNAseq data.

Now after we have realized the importance of large perplexity limit for tSNE, let us evaluate tSNE at large perplexity on the 2D linear manifold of World Map data set (3023 points) that was introduced in my previous post. The full code for generating the World Map data set is available on my github.

Here we can observe that tSNE falsely places South America between Africa and North America at perplexities 500 and 1000. However, when perplexity reaches 2000, we get almost a perfect reconstruction of the original World Map data set, where all relative distances between the continents seem to be well preserved. This might seem reassuring and suggest that if one wants to preserve more of a global structure in the data with tSNE it should be enough just to increase the perplexity value. However, here comes the catch that can be clearly seen if we project the original linear 2D World Map data set onto a non-linear manifold such as a sphere, in this way we mimic the 3D globe with continents mapped to the surface of the sphere. Let us run tSNE with a large perplexity value on the non-linear 3D globe/sphere data set and compare its output with PCA and UMAP. In addition, we will also project the 2D data set onto other famous non-linear manifolds such as S-shaped surface and Swiss Roll and run PCA and tSNE / UMAP with large perplexity / n_neighbor. Note that both tSNE and UMAP were identically initialized with PCA.

Here we observe a remarkable similarity between PCA and tSNE plots. What happened? Since the internal dimensionality of the 3D non-linear manifolds (Sphere, S-shape and Swiss Roll) is still two, one would expect that a proper dimension reduction method could recover the original 2D World Map data. The intuition behind why PCA fails to achieve it is that PCA searches for axes of largest variation in the data via affine transformation such as rotation, flip, translation, stretching etc. However, by rotating the non-linear manifolds one will not find an axis that appropriately captures the variation of interest that is the positions of the continents in the World Map. Instead, the spiral, S-curve and circle revealed by PCA indeed capture the most of the variation that can be detected via a linear transformation. It is understandable why PCA fails on a non-linear manifold, but why doesn’t tSNE perform any better? This is not unique for the World Map embeddings into a non-linear 3D manifold but can be detected even on a well-behaved benchmark MNIST data set, i.e. the tSNE plots for large perplexity values equal to 500 and 3000 resemble the PCA plot.

What is going on? Wasn’t tSNE at large perplexity supposed to reconstruct the original data with correctly kept global structure as it seemingly happened for the 2D linear World Map at perplexity = 2000 shown at the beginning of this section? To answer this we need to look inside the tSNE algorithm and realize that due to vanishing gradient in the gradient descent, tSNE degrades to PCA.

In order to understand what happens with tSNE at large perplexity we need to recall that tSNE is based on the following four equations, see my post for more information about strengths and weaknesses of tSNE:

and check a few important concepts such as distribution of pairwise euclidean distances of the data, distribution of sigma values (the bandwidth of Gaussian kernel in the Eq. 1), distribution of high-dimensional probabilities to find data points at a distance (Eq. 1), distribution of low-dimensional probabilities (Eq. 3), and finally distribution of gradient values of KL-divergence (Eq. 4). Sadly, all those metrics are not easy to extract from the current implementations of tSNE (e.g. scikitlearn or Rtsne) without hacking the codes. In particular, we need to check if the gradient of the KL-divergence vanishes at large perplexity as this would mean that the gradient descent within the tSNE never properly starts after its initialization with e.g. PCA.
In principal, looking into tSNE codes from scikitlearn, we could find functions _joint_probabilities and _kl_divergence that could provide the information:

Here we can see that the KL-gradient decreases down to almost zero with the growth of the perplexity parameter. For more comprehensive information for the future, it makes sense to implement tSNE from scratch. The code below numerically reproduces the output from scikitlearn tSNE implementation but is a bit more compact and hopefully more understandable.

The advantage of programming tSNE from scratch is that we can extract any information we want, such as evolution of KL-gradient at different values of perplexity. We can immediately see that the KL-gradient very quickly drops down to zero at large perplexity, hence the coordinates of the embeddings stop updating, and we end up with just the coordinates at initialization.

Therefore if we initialize tSNE with a PCA and increase perplexity, we are at risk to end up with a PCA plot but not a tSNE. Note, that for simplicity I use the term PCA although more correctly would be to say that tSNE degrades to the Multi-Dimensional Scaling (MDS) plot. PCA and MDS are similar in many aspects and I refer to PCA (not MDS) as a more popular and known technique.

But why does the KL-gradient disappear at large perplexity? Taking a closer look reveals an interesting interplay between P and Q, i.e. the high- and low-dimensional probabilities of observing data points at a certain distance. The two probabilities become comparable at large perplexity, i.e. P/Q approaches 1 and as it follows from Eq.4, the KL-gradient vanishes and tSNE deteriorates.

In sloppy notations, recalling that tSNE has an important hyper-parameter, early exaggeration, that is a multiplication factor for the high-dimensional probability P, one can write down the tSNE deterioration condition as:

where alpha is the early exaggeration, N is the sample size, sigma is related to perplexity, X and Y are mean euclidean distances between data points in high and low dimensions. Hence, the equation above connects the most important hyperparameters of tSNE, except maybe for learning rate that does not matter when P = Q condition is fulfilled at large perplexity.

In this post, we have learnt that one needs to increase perplexity values using tSNE on large data sets in order to obtain more distinct clusters and preserve more of a global structure in the data, that becomes important for biological interpretation of the distances between different clusters. However, increasing perplexity may result in degradation of non-linear tSNE down to a linear PCA / MDS dimension reduction, when the KL-gradient vanishes so the algorithm never properly starts. This sometimes can be falsely interpreted as a “perfect reconstruction of original data” if one runs tSNE on linear data, but becomes obviously wrong when running tSNE at large perplexities on non-linear data.

In the comments below let me know which analytical techniques from Life Sciences seem especially mysterious to you and I will try to cover them in the future posts. Check the codes from the post on my Github. Follow me at Medium Nikolay Oskolkov, in Twitter @NikolayOskolkov and do connect in Linkedin. Next time I will turn to Evolutionary Biology and explain how to estimate population size back in time using Ancient DNA, stay tuned.
